awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--Quantifying the Impact of Radiation Belt Electron Precipitation on Atmospheric Reactive Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) and Ozone (O3)
awd_abstract_narration:
This work will study how certain energetic particles in the magnetosphere affect and change of the composition of the region of the atmosphere closer to the surface of Earth. Improved understanding of how different regions of Earth's atmosphere are linked will enhance our predictive capabilities to protect satellites and other technological assets from the effects of solar and magnetospheric storms. This grant will also develop interdisciplinary collaborations across geoscience (magnetosphere, ionosphere, energetic particles, upper and middle atmosphere).

The research will quantify the contribution of energetic electron precipitation from the Van Allen radiation belts to the production of reactive nitrogen oxides (NOx) in the mesosphere and stratosphere and its resultant impact on ozone (O3). Observations from the FIREBIRD (Focused Investigations of Relativistic Electron Burst Intensity, Range, and Dynamics) satellites and Van Allen Probes will be used to produce the particle spectra and the global maps of electron flux that will be used to drive the WACCM-DART model which implements a new D-region chemical scheme to calculate NOx. By adding this new source, i.e., electron flux from the radiation belts, to the WACCM-DART, the deficits of the NOx in the model simulation are expected to be tackled. Once the model can be validated and favorably compare with observations, the impacts of the radiation belt REP on the NOx in the mesosphere and stratosphere, and the O3 in the stratosphere will be quantified.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project uses observations from multiple satellites to quantify how particles from the magnetosphere (in near-Earth space) affect the Earth's atmosphere. Products include an electron precipitation dataset from 2013-2019 that combines observations from two NSF FIREBIRD-II CubeSats in polar Earth orbit near the top of the atmosphere and two NASA Van Allen Probes spacecraft traveling through the radiation belts. This work confirms that electron precipitation from the outer Van Allen radiation belt in the magnetosphere significantly influences the chemistry, dynamics, and energy transfer of the mid to high latitude atmosphere, especially enhancement of nitrogen oxides at altitudes below 90 km in polar winter when air mass descent can lead to the catalytic destruction of ozone in the stratosphere.

The resulting electron precipitation dataset provides unique information regarding electrons at energies important for ionization of the middle atmosphere. Simulations using NCAR's Whole Atmosphere Community Climate Model (WACCM) suggests that the effects of radiation belt electrons on the middle atmosphere may be larger than currently predicted from the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP6) particle forcing based on NOAA POES and ESA MetOp MEPED data. In order to compare FIREBIRD-II observations directly to POES and MetOp, this study targeted high resolution downloads during spacecraft conjunctions. While high-resolution FIREBIRD-II measurements follow the same general trends as NOAA POES and ESA MetOp, they are also able to capture variability at lower flux as a result of instrument geometry. Analysis of FIREBIRD-II data from 2015-2019 also shows that high-energy (>1 MeV) electron precipitation peaks at McIlwain L shell 4.5 and that background precipitation increases and strong precipitation events decrease in the declining phase of the solar cycle.

This project has provided a link between the NSF CEDAR and NSF GEM communities, has supported the research of undergraduate students in Physics, and has enhanced the careers of women in magnetospheric and atmospheric sciences. The electron precipitation maps and modeling experiments from this project also helped NCAR collaborators develop the capacity for WACCM to directly read in electron precipitation at the top of the atmosphere and calculate ionization rates within the model atmosphere, a benefit to both the magnetospheric and atmospheric communities. Outcomes encourage future missions that measure electron flux near the top of the atmosphere with more resolved pitch angles and energies as well as modeling studies to determine how localized changes in ozone from electron precipitation influence atmospheric dynamics and radiative processes. In addition, this work demonstrates the value of CubeSats to enhance both scientific research and education, including research at the undergraduate level.
